Indeed, by the 'Asr [al-'asr], God the Exalted has swornโand it is the time following the zenith until sunsetโto indicate the immense significance of watching over the times [al-awqat] and filling them with acts of obedience ['ibadat], as He, the Exalted, has said: "By the 'Asr [al-'asr]." From this oath, it becomes clear that the supreme intended purpose from the creation of the night and the day and the measuring of the sun and the moon by calculation is not merely benefiting from the affairs of the world [al-dunya], but rather so that the servant may know the measures of times [al-azminah] and occupy every portion of them with trade for the Hereafter [al-akhirah], as He, the Exalted, has clarified in His saying: "And He is the One who made the night and the day in succession for whoever desires to remember or desires gratitude." Thus, the 'Asr is one of the seven litanies [awrad] of the day; it is fitting for the servant to observe it with remembrance [dhikr] and supplication [du'a'], following the example of the righteous predecessors [al-salaf al-salih] who used to supplicate their Lord at morning and evening, desiring His Face. So let that be a path to the pleasure [ridwan] of God and to attaining success through His sought-after bounty.
